description: Expected SSR score ranges for test product concepts. These are hypothetical ranges based on semantic similarity to purchase intent anchors.
methodology: Scores are derived from cosine similarity between free-text responses and the positive anchor 'I would definitely buy this product.' Higher scores indicate stronger purchase intent.

positive_1.name: Free Morning Coffee
positive_1.rationale: Free premium product with clear value proposition. Should generate highly positive responses across demographics.

positive_2.name: AI Personal Assistant
positive_2.rationale: Tech product with broad appeal but varying relevance. Tech-savvy personas should score higher.

negative_1.name: Overpriced Plastic Cup
negative_1.rationale: Obviously overpriced with no value. Should generate consistently negative responses.

neutral_1.name: New Email App
neutral_1.rationale: Commodity product with incremental differentiation. Mixed responses expected.

neutral_2.name: Weather Widget
neutral_2.rationale: Free utility with limited excitement. Mildly positive to neutral responses.

mixed_1.name: Smart Meal Planner
mixed_1.rationale: Niche product with strong appeal to health-conscious personas. High variance expected.

niche_1.name: Vintage Vinyl Record Player
niche_1.rationale: Specialty product with strong niche appeal. Music lovers should score high, others low. Highest variance expected.

validation_criteria.variance_check: All products should have std_dev > expected_std_dev_min
validation_criteria.range_check: Mean score should fall within expected_range for 80%+ of runs
validation_criteria.ordering_check: Mean scores should follow: negative_1 < neutral < positive
validation_criteria.cost_check: Total cost for N=100 should be < $1.00
validation_criteria.time_check: Execution time for N=100 should be < 120 seconds

notes: These expected ranges are estimates based on the SSR methodology
Actual results may vary based on LLM temperature and persona diversity
Real embeddings will show higher variance than mock embeddings
Run multiple trials (n>=3) to validate consistency
